abstract.text: Create standard and custom user-facing parameters for your plug-in that will appear in the inspector.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Once a plug-in is invoked by a host application, the host application asks for the plug-in’s parameter list by calling the
method. This method is declared in the
protocol, which is inherited by the
protocol. The host application then displays the parameters in its inspector.
The FxPlug SDK includes methods for adding these standard types of parameters:
Floating-point, integer, and percent sliders
Angle slider
Toggle button (checkbox)
RGB or RGBA color
Point
Popup menu
String
Histogram
Gradient
Path picker
Font menu
Help button
Push button
Image Reference
Group
In the
method, a plug-in first calls the
method (defined by the
framework) to get the host API object that implements the protocol. It then adds parameters, one by one, using methods in the
protocol.
For example, the following code shows an
method from a simple opacity filter:
Parameter IDs must be in the range of
. IDs outside of this range are invalid.

code: paramAPI.addFloatSlider(withName: "Opacity", parameterID: 1, defaultValue: 1.0, parameterMin: 0.0, parameterMax: 100.0, sliderMin: 0.0, sliderMax: 10.0, delta: 0.1, parameterFlags: FxParameterFlags(kFxParameterFlag_DEFAULT))

inlineContent.text: A Mix slider parameter is automatically added filter plug-ins, and a Publish OSC toggle parameter is automatically added in Motion to any plug-in that contains onscreen controls. The Publish OSC toggle parameter is never visible in Final Cut Pro.
In addition to the standard parameter types, you can use the following method to create a custom parameter with an opaque data type:
Each custom parameter must be associated with a custom parameter view, which is defined by the methods in
When a user changes a parameter control for an FxPlug plug-in, the host application calls the
plug-in method. This is useful for a plug-in that changes the state of other parameters. For example, if the user changes a toggle button, the plug-in can hide or reveal other parameters during

content.text: Handle user interaction for custom UI parameters

inlineContent.text: Custom UI parameters let developers draw directly to a custom UI and create their own controls in a space that the host application makes for them in the inspector. The host application handles user interaction for custom parameters in a different way than standard UI parameters. For example, when you develop custom parameters, they must conform to the
protocol. An example of this can be found in the
sample plug-in.
In your plug-in, custom parameters conform to the
protocol by implementing a
method that provides an
subclass to the host app. Like any other

subclass, this custom view draws itself in a window and receives notification of any user actions such as mouse, key, and tablet events. In response to user events, the custom view sets parameter values. Usually it sets the value of a custom parameter. The host application notices that a parameter value has changed and calls the plug-in to render with the new parameter values.
The plug-in can create a custom view object programmatically or retrieve it from a
file (created in Xcode’s Interface Builder and placed in your plug-in’s
folder).
Your plug-in’s custom view methods must call the
host API
method before your plug-in accesses any parameter values, and then call the
method after it has finished accessing the parameter values. This lets the host application set up and restore the internal state.

content.text: Update versioning for your plug-in’s parameters

inlineContent.text: As you develop plug-ins over time, you may need to deprecate, add, or update your parameters, like changing a default value or range.
To ensure that projects using your older plug-ins still function correctly, use
to find out the version of the plug-in that’s used with a project. With this information, you can branch your parameter code, update your project, and handle special cases as needed.

For example, if you create a version 1 brightness filter with a floating point slider and apply it to a project, the project saves the plug-in’s version number along with the slider value. On subsequent launches of the project, you can query
and check for a version number of
See
for more information.
If you later update the brightness filter to use a second parameter, update the version of your plug-in. Then, on subsequent launches, do a version check and add a second path for a version number of

abstract.text: The infrastructure for drawing, printing, and handling events in an app.
Simplify user interaction by using onscreen controls for your FxPlug plug-in.
Create custom effects plug-ins for Final Cut Pro and Motion.
Version plug-ins to add new capabilities, or obsolete them to remove them from the Motion Library.
Exchange data with Final Cut Pro, and create effects plug-ins for Final Cut Pro and Motion.
Commands that you can tell the host to perform.
Adds functionality to move the playhead to a specific timeline time.
Defines the methods the host application provides to support a custom parameter view.
Tells the host application that the plug-in is done accessing parameters.
Prepares the host to access parameters.
Defines the methods a plug-in needs to implement to support keyframing custom parameters.
Defines the methods a plug-in needs to implement to associate a custom NSView with one of its parameters.
Provides an NSView to be associated with the given parameter.
Allows your plugin to create parameters on-the-fly.
Constants used to identify which channel a histogram operation should apply to.
Defines the methods provided by the host application to create parameters.
These constants specify the characteristics of parameters display.
Defines the functions the application provides to retrieve parameter values.
Adds a method to retrieve the image information about an image parameter.
Defines the functions the application provides to set parameter values.
Defines the functions the application provides to set parameter flags.
An API that defines the methods to retrieve information about paths, shapes, and masks the user has drawn on an object.
A protocol that allows the plug-in to request that the host create a window.
A protocol that allows the plug-in to request that the host create a window with a defined minimum and maximum size.
The designated initializer for your plug-in for rendering only certain portions of the plug-in’s output, referred to as tiles.
Tells the host application what parameters your plug-in requires.
Executes when the host detects that a parameter has changed.
An API that defines the methods that the host app implements to handle plug-in management of the host app’s undo queue.
A collection of methods that a host application implements to identify the plug-in version used by a project when it was first created.
Provides the version number of a plug-in that a project uses.
